thread.title: Janet Jackson’s brothers call her baby boy “beautiful” and share what they REALLY think about Paris becoming famous
thread.title_full: Janet Jackson’s brothers call her baby boy “beautiful” and share what they REALLY think about Paris becoming famous

author: Lara Martin
title: Janet Jackson’s brothers call her baby boy “beautiful” and share what they REALLY think about Paris becoming famous
text:
Janet Jackson’s brothers call her baby boy “beautiful” and share what they REALLY think about Paris becoming famous Tito and Jackie Jackson gave a family update during appearance on Good Morning Britain on Tuesday Share Tito and Jackie Jackson on GMB (Photo: ITV) Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Tito and Jackie Jackson have opened up about life in their famous family, gushing about sister Janet ’s newborn son and the career path of the Jacksons’ next generation. 
The siblings appeared on ITV’s Good Morning Britain on Tuesday to discuss The Jacksons’ 50th anniversary world tour, but also spoke about life within their iconic family. 
It grew even bigger in January when Janet, 50, announced the birth of her first child, son Eissa Al Mana with businessman husband Wissam Al Mana . They gave a family update on GMB (Photo: ITV) Janet and husband Wissam became parents in January (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Janet Jackson welcomes her first child at 50 Share this video Watch Next 
Since then, the new mum has been keeping a low profile with her son, who remains away from the limelight, but her brothers updated GMB and said that all is well. 
“Janet had a beautiful baby boy. It’s all good. Everyone’s fine. Everything’s great,” said Jackie. 
The next generation of Jacksons also includes late brother Michael’s three children, Prince, 20, Paris, 18, and 15-year-old Blanket. 
Discussing how they feel about the youngsters getting into showbiz, Jackie said: “I guess it’s in their blood. They watched us growing up when they were young. They love the business. That’s what they want to do, so go ahead and do it. That’s how we look at it.” They spoke about the next generation of Jacksons (Photo: ITV) Paris Jackson pictured at the Grammys in February (Photo: Getty Images North America) Read More Paris Jackson sparks rumours she's dating TOWIE star Lydia Bright's ex-boyfriend, Tom Kilbey 
Tito them said: “There’s a lot of talent in the family. We have a lot of singers and actors and actresses so you can’t stop a person’s dreams. They see their aunts and uncles doing what they do – usually we try and be like our parents and siblings and that’s what they do.” 
“I just tell them to keep their head on straight and use good judgement,” he added. “That’s the important thing.” 
The chat then turned whether fame is ever worth it given the downsides that come with being in the public eye. 
“That’s part of the business,” reasoned Jackie. “You’re going to have ups and downs in this industry. They all go through it, that’s part of the business. But you’ve got to stay strong. The brothers spoke via video link (Photo: ITV) They're touring this year (Photo: ITV) Read More Paris Jackson wishes happy birthday to little brother Blanket with vintage snap as he turns 15 
“The most important thing is you’re supporting your fans. The fans are the ones that keep us going because they love the music. We do it for them, if it wasn’t for them we wouldn’t be where we are today. It’s a very tough business but it’s fun. It’s what you make of it.” 
The Jacksons will be showing how much they love their fans with the upcoming world tour in support of their 50th anniversary; the surviving members’ will play Blenheim Palace, Oxford on June 18. 
“If you’ve noticed there’s certain entertainers that just can’t put down the microphone, we happen to be a family of that," said Tito. 
"Thinking of The Rolling Stones and B.B. King and Sammy Davis Jr and Sinatra, all of these guys. We just love performing, it’s what we’re here to do.” They will keep Michael's legacy alive (Photo: REUTERS) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
